Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We are going to do the following steps: 1. Count the number of events per case_id. 2. Filter the cases to keep only those with count <= 6. 3. Join back to the original table to get the events for the filtered cases.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Alternatively, we can use a subquery to filter the case_ids and then join.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Let's break it down: Step 1: Count events per case_id (we'll call this subquery event_counts). Step 2: Filter the event_counts to have counts <= 6. Step 3: Join the original event_log table with the filtered event counts to get only the events for those cases.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: We can do: WITH event_counts AS ( SELECT case_id, COUNT(*) as event_count FROM event_log GROUP BY case_id ) SELECT el.* FROM event_log el JOIN event_counts ec ON el.case_id = ec.case_id WHERE ec.event_count <= 6;

Name: Validation - PE
Text: However, note: the problem says filters out any cases containing more than six events, meaning we keep cases with 6 or fewer. But note: the above query will include every event from every case that has <=6 events.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Alternatively, we can use a subquery in the WHERE clause without CTE, but CTE is clearer. Let me write the query accordingly.
